# Summary of Article from nippon.com (January 29, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Polling conducted**: January 27-28, 2026 (via telephone and internet)
- **Polling organizations**: Yomiuri Shimbun and Nikkei
- **Results published**: January 29, 2026 morning editions
- **Timing**: Polls taken just after formal campaigning began; lower house was dissolved on January 23

## Current Seat Distribution (at time of dissolution):
- LDP: 196 seats
- Nippon Ishin no Kai (coalition partner): 34 seats
- Coalition total: 230 seats
- **Majority threshold**: 233 seats (out of 465 total)

## Poll Findings:

According to both Yomiuri and Nikkei reports:
- LDP is "favorably positioned" to greatly increase seats through both single-seat districts and proportional representation
- LDP has the prospect of achieving a **simple majority (233+ seats) without its junior coalition partner**
- A **"stable majority" of 243 seats** is within range for the LDP (this would allow the LDP to chair all permanent lower house committees)
- The coalition's joint seat total could achieve an **"absolute stable majority" of 261 seats** (would allow coalition to chair and maintain majority of seats in committees)

## Opposition Performance:
- The **Centrist Reform Alliance** (newly formed from the Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan and Kōmeitō) is likely to struggle due to insufficient name recognition
</Summary>

# Summary of NHK Poll on Takaichi Cabinet and 2026 Election

## Key Polling Data

**Cabinet Approval Ratings:**
- Approval rate: 59% (down 3 points from two weeks earlier)
- Disapproval rate: 26% (up 5 points from two weeks earlier)

**Poll Methodology:**
- Conducted by NHK via phone survey
- Target sample: 3,630 people
- Survey period: Three days through Sunday (specific date not provided)
- Actual respondents: 1,564 people (43% response rate)

## Views on Lower House Dissolution

Regarding Prime Minister Takaichi's decision to dissolve the Lower House for a snap election:
- 34% said the move was appropriate
- 49% said it was not appropriate
- 17% were undecided or gave no answer

## Most Important Policy Areas

When asked which policy area is most important in deciding their vote (choose one from six options):
- 41% - Measures to deal with high prices
- 18% - Social security and measures to deal with declining birthrate
- 17% - Diplomacy and security
- 7% - Money in politics
- 5% - Policies on foreign nationals
- 2% - Constitutional amendments

## Desired Election Outcome

Regarding the most desirable balance of power for the upcoming general election:
- 24% - Hope the LDP wins a single-party majority
- 22% - Hope the ruling coalition secures a majority
- 32% - Want ruling and opposition camps to win almost equal numbers of seats
- 11% - Hope the opposition wins a majority

**Note:** Combined support for LDP majority scenarios (single-party or coalition) = 46%

## Consumption Tax Preferences

Views on consumption tax changes to address rising prices:
- 19% - Maintain current rate
- 40% - Lower rate for limited items such as food
- 18% - Reduce rate for all items
- 14% - Abolish consumption tax entirely
</Summary>

# Summary of CFR Article on Political Realignment and the 2026 Japanese Election

**Date:** January 28, 2026  
**Authors:** Sheila A. Smith (Senior Fellow) and Chris Baylor (Research Associate)

## Key Facts and Timeline

- **Election Date:** February 8, 2026 (Lower House election called by PM Takaichi on January 23)
- **Takaichi's Approval Ratings:** 
  - Hovered around 70% for months
  - Dipped to around 60% as campaign opened
- **Previous LDP Electoral Performance:**
  - 2024 Lower House: Lost 56 seats, fell into minority position
  - 2025 Upper House: Lost majority, won only 39 of 125 contested seats

## Political Realignment

**Coalition Changes:**
- LDP's longstanding coalition with Komeito dissolved in October 2025 after Takaichi assumed leadership
- Takaichi formed new coalition with Ishin no Kai (conservative Osaka-based party)
- Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan (CDPJ) joined forces with Komeito to form new party: Centrist Reform Alliance (CRA)
- Democratic Party of the People (DPP) alignment remains uncertain

## Key Issue: Growing Presence of Non-Japanese

**Tourism Statistics (from Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport, and Tourism):**
- 2025: Approximately 42.7 million visitors (15.8% increase from 2024)
- Example: Biei, Hokkaido has 9,344 residents but hosts 2.4 million visitors annually

**Foreign Residents and Workers:**
- Over 3.9 million foreigners currently reside in Japan (5% increase from 2024)
- Chinese residents: Over 900,000 (largest group, 30,000 increase from 2024)
- Foreign workers: Record 2.3 million in 2024, expected higher for 2025
- Worker origins: Vietnam (24.8%), China (17.8%), Philippines (10.7%)

**Takaichi's Position:**
- Only candidate in LDP leadership race (out of 5) who explicitly raised concerns about foreigner behavior
- Quoted: "I, Takaichi Sanae, will devote myself to protect the traditions that made Japan an irreplaceable country if foreigners trample on the feelings of the Japanese"
- Created new ministerial office for "society of well-ordered and harmonious coexistence" headed by Onoda Kimi

**Public Opinion Polls on Immigration/Tourism:**
- November 2025 Asahi Shimbun poll: 56% believe Japan needs fewer visitors and immigrants; 66% back Takaichi's tougher stance
- December 2025 Yomiuri Shimbun poll: 59% oppose foreign laborers
- NHK poll: 70% support raising bar for obtaining Japanese citizenship

**Sanseitō Party:**
- Newcomer party with "Japanese first" agenda
- Won 14 seats in 2025 Upper House election
- Gained additional 5.6 million proportional votes from 2022 to 2025
- Challenged LDP's hold on conservative districts

## Expert Analysis/Context

The article frames this as a test of whether Takaichi can repair the LDP's erosion of voter confidence. The authors suggest Takaichi is addressing the immigration/tourism issue both due to personal concern (her Nara constituency) and to bring conservative voters back to the LDP who were disgruntled under former PM Ishiba.

**Note:** The article appears to be cut off mid-sentence at the end of the extracted content.
</Summary>

## Article Summary: "General Election 2026: Little Chance to Return to the 'Neo-1955' Status Quo Politics"

**Source:** nippon.com  
**Date:** January 28, 2026

### Key Points:

**Historical Context:**
- The author describes a "neo-1955 setup" - a period of relative political stability and LDP dominance lasting approximately 12 years from Prime Minister Abe Shinzō's second administration (2012) onwards
- This stability has been "unraveling since the 2024 general election," with Japan entering a period of "political recalibration" continuing through 2025

**Recent Political Turbulence:**
The article notes that few major media outlets predicted several major political developments:
- LDP's "crushing defeats" in the October 2024 House of Representatives election
- LDP's defeat in the July 2025 House of Councillors election
- The "meteoric rise" of newcomers like the Democratic Party for the People (DPFP) and Sanseitō
- Takaichi's victory in the LDP leadership race
- Kōmeitō's withdrawal from the ruling coalition
- Takaichi's call for a snap election in early 2026
- The unexpected merger of the Constitutional Democratic Party and Kōmeitō into a new party

**Structural Constraints on LDP Power:**
- The ruling coalition currently **lacks a majority in the House of Councillors**
- The House of Councillors has unusually strong powers and can block government-backed legislation
- Only half of upper house seats are contested every three years, meaning the **earliest the LDP could regain a majority there is 2031** - six years away
- Even if the LDP wins a single-party majority in the February 8 general election, the government would still need to cooperate with opposition parties (like Nippon Ishin no Kai and DPFP) to pass legislation

**Author's Conclusion:**
The author (a political scientist) concludes that regardless of the February 8 election outcome, a return to the centralized authority enjoyed during Abe's second term is "clearly not possible in the foreseeable future." Prime Minister Takaichi's aspirations to restore the "neo-1955 setup" are "unlikely to be realized any time soon."

**Note:** This is an opinion piece by a political scientist providing structural analysis rather than specific polling data or election predictions.
</Summary>

# Summary: Japan election becomes high-stakes gamble for Takaichi as personal popularity faces tougher opposition

**Source:** CNBC, January 30, 2026, by Lim Hui Jie

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Electoral Context:**
- Election date: February 8, 2026
- House of Representatives has 465 seats; 233 needed for majority
- Before dissolution (Jan 23), LDP and Japan Innovation Party held 230 seats, with 3 independents voting alongside giving them a one-seat effective majority

**Approval Ratings:**
- Takaichi's personal approval: above 70% (until recently)
- LDP party approval: just under 30%

**Economic Indicators:**
- Inflation above Bank of Japan's target for 45 consecutive months
- Most recent inflation: 2.1%; full-year inflation: 3.2%
- Real wages fell for 11 consecutive months year-on-year in 2025
- Real wages have fallen every year since 2022
- Yen weakened to near 160 against USD in early 2026

**Policy Measures:**
- Record $783 billion budget proposed for fiscal year starting April 1
- $135 billion stimulus package introduced in 2025

## Expert Opinions (Named Sources):

**Kazuto Suzuki** (Director, Institute of Geoeconomics, Tokyo):
- Takaichi is trying to make the election "a referendum on whether the people accept [her] as a prime minister or not"

**Mireya Solís** (Director, Center for Asia Policy Studies, Brookings Institution):
- Takaichi is "betting on her high levels of public approval and fragmentation among the opposition parties to carry the day"

**Jesper Koll** (Expert Director, Monex Group):
- Described Takaichi as an "inspiration" to older and younger voters
- Her personal appeal may drive a "landslide victory"
- Attributed her appeal to being "self-made" from "normal working-class family background"

**Kristi Govella** (Associate Professor, University of Oxford; Japan Chair, CSIS):
- May be "difficult" to frame vote as referendum on Takaichi given her short time in office
- "If the LDP manages to gain a clear majority in this election, it will be entirely attributable to Takaichi's personal popularity—little else has changed since July when the LDP was drubbed at the polls"

**Ross Schaap** (Head of Research, Geo Quant):
- Voters appear to be "discounting" inflation concerns and are "fine for the most part with Ms Takaichi's press to be expansionary"
- Opposition coordination "could overcome the high approval"
- "If there's high turnout, it could be a good day for Takaichi. If there's not a high turnout, then it will be a close race"

## Additional Context:

**Coalition Changes:**
- Takaichi leads coalition of LDP and Japan Innovation Party (untested coalition)
- This followed end of 26-year partnership with Komeito in October 2025
- Former coalition partner Komeito has now joined with Constitutional Democratic Party of Japan to form new Centrist Reform Alliance

**Recent Electoral History:**
- LDP suffered setbacks under former PM Shigeru Ishiba, who defeated Takaichi in 2024 party leadership race
- LDP lost Lower House majority in 2024 snap election
- Ishiba resigned September 2025 after LDP lost Upper House control in July 2025

**Takaichi's Personal Statement:**
- On Jan 19, said she was "putting my future as prime minister on this election"
</Summary>
